No I'm kidding I can't rate this early or judge at just a clip of the actor's. Until then..derp...
And the world never heard from this again. Kinda weird to show a dub promo 8 months ago and not know a thing about it now.

Jin's voice though. XD Yuma sounded oh so very bored when he said trigger on. And maybe don't give him that double expresso coffee he wanted. I would love to just here Jin talk. I mean really, that voice is perfect for him. XD

+TwitchingFool0 Around the first fight against other human-like enemies it gets really good. Mainly with it's strategy and world building, this series has probably some of the best written strategies I've ever seen. But this dub just seems so... eeehhhhhhh................. I mean, don't get me wrong, I usually prefer dubs, but this sounds like something you'd hear from a mediocre abridged series. If you're ok with it then whatever, but I'd recommend the subbed version over this. Not only does it sound a lot more competent, but the sub is pretty much at the end of the first season by now at episode 45 or something and almost caught up to where the manga currently is.

They detail this huge world, and make it so immersive, but as it is just a manga you can't always get the information that you want.

The manga did exceptionally well actually; the anime was kind of a failure though, its not all bad, just mostly. Of course you most likely don't buy manga as it serializes in Japan, so i don't know if you actually care about the sale #s of shonen jump. But it does determine a lot at the series level. 

The three things that have been most damaging to World Triggers success are Toei, The Writer's Health (as it limits the amount of content that can be put out), and lastly the content. Fruits basket my beloved

Fruits basket was the first manga I've ever read and I was super young when I read it. There was parts I didn't understand fully but I felt. The scene where kyo's dad holds him up in the air and says "From now on, you'll have to breathe the air of higher places." I grew up with a single parent household and reading that made something click in my brain. A deep feeling of understanding of my mom and why she worked so hard for my brother and I. This manga has shaped me as a person and my understanding of love. It taught me that love is complex but beautiful. It comes in all shapes and sizes. All colors and ways. It taught me that change is ok. Change is natural and scary. But good. Even when you have bad change. Even if you lose something or someone you love, even when it feels like there is no hope and that nothing will get better. Even in our darkest moments its ok. You'll be ok. It taught me that everything ends eventually. And that's such a scary thought but that's what makes it beautiful. If everything was forever then we wouldn't understand how beautiful and precious life is. We wouldn't understand the space and magnitude that the people we love hold in our hearts and mind.  I have a space on my shelf of this story, the whole collection, and it'll remain there until it gets passed on. I hope everyone gets a chance to read this manga and learn the lesson of life and love and changing that it holds.

Watching this after finishing the show brings a whole new feeling to it.
Fruits Basket Mondays are now celebrated by me and will never be forgotten

Just to say it
It is a collaboration between Too Kyoo Games and Studio Pierrot.
Too Kyoo Games was funded by Kazutaka Kodaka and Kotaro Uchikoshi years back as a gaming studio and on the day of their funding they announced 4 titles, 3 being games and 1 being well this anime series Akudama Drive with Studio Pierrot.
The creator of this series is Kazutaka Kodaka(Danganronpa series).
This anime was supposed to come out this summer season but had to be delay due to virus.
Danganronpa+Persona= Akudama drive

Long ago, a war broke out in Japan that pitted Kantou against Kansai and divided the country. Kansai became dependent on Kantou, but slowly the police and government began losing control of Kansai to criminals known as Akudama.

I finished watching season 2 a day ago and I have to say... ...I think I'll just stick with the first season, the paladin movie was okay even if it felt like three episodes crammed into one, season 2 on the other hand felt a tiny bit... "meh". This season just didn't quite have the same impact as the first, there were still some blood and gore (mostly on the goblins) and some graphic images, the only stuff like that stood out the most was in the first four episode ark with that young wizard brat while the rest of the season started to focus a little more on the slice of life elements ...and... bits of fanservice no less (6 & 10). I did like first ark of season 2 like when we learn more about who that wizard kid really is which helps give more depth to Goblin Slayer and Priestess who's courage and strength begins to grow more and more as she ends up gaining a silver rank in the end of the ark. So yeah not give anything else away but in my opinion the first ark and the final ark with a princess rescue mission were the only parts of Season 2 I thought were good, the middle of it was just okay. Overall I didn't think Season 2 was good as Season 1 but definitely not at all worst, I'm just hoping it might get a little better in the third season if they'll ever make one in the six years. But what do you guys think?

That's the general theme of Goblin slayer as a whole. The idea that there are people out in these fantasy settings that see goblins or any other rookie-level enemy as an actual problem and have to resort to their wits and whatever they can get as weaponry when the heroes are fighting large-scale enemies worth their time. Over cockyness on par with our favourite rpg characters gets you killed like the events of episode 1. Magic exists, yet people only ever use one or two spells ever in compsrison to Cloud's or Chrono's entire library of techniques. Hell, Goblin slayer isn't even a main character in his universe. In the final episode, the real "heroes" are having a parade in their honour in the middle of town while the cast we follow are happy out, celebrating the fact that they took on a large goblin nest and lived.

+Atlas As I've said before, some things in Japanese don't translate well in English. I'm not a script adapter so I can't tell you exactly how hard it is. However I've heard Eric Vale, who does adapt scripts, say it's not an easy task. As for Prison School it was one line, and that happened a year ago. In conclusion, I'm just going to tell you what I tell other dub haters. It's cool if you don't like dubbed anime, just don't be an asshole about it. You can always just watch the subbed version.

Â @shivam9023Â  Of course you should. At least try it out... Bakemonogatari has a certain style that not everyone may like; it's surrealistic and weird, but the series is nonetheless amazing. It truly depends on what you watch and what you read. If you don't like anime, it wouldn't surprise me if you still like the Monogatari series. I have never given any sort of fiction a 10/10, but Bakemonogatari is an 8.25/10, and the Monogatari series overall would be a 9/10. It's a hot mess; self-indulgent and witty, but try it. Won't hurt.

2019 was such an awesome year. Carole & Tuesday is just....awesome!
Yeah we had an Invader Zim movie on Netflix too, but I just love Carole & Tuesday too much.

I honestly think it's funny knowing that Gus's (I think that's his name. The guy who becomes Carole and Tuesday's manager) has the same Japanese voice actor as Thorkell from Vinland saga. The mental image of a war loving giant being a manager in another universe is kind of funny, but maybe that's just me. Love both series though, so I'm not complaining!

Urusei Yatsura is one of the best anime ever and I believe it changed everything about the genre when it came out in 1981. 194 magical episodes and 6 movies. Beautiful Dreamer is SUCH A GOOD MOVIE!!! Tell me it wasn't the inspiration for Groundhog Day. Mendou sounds AWFUL with his Kurai yo, semai yo, kowai yo. That was a great long running gag and I just don't like the voice here at all :( Maybe it's because I've watched the series three times, but it all looks off. I'll still watch the heck out of it... but it would've been better with all 194 and 6 movies getting remastered

Despite having a different tone from the manga/anime, this is the best of the Urusei Yatsura film.

Film director Shinichiro Watanabe said that this anime had huge impact on him:

"â€œOf those three anime movies, Urusei Yatsura 2: Beautiful Dreamer is my favorite. I really felt the movie exhibited great freedom of creativity. So many crazy things happen in a very surreal way. It felt like anything could happen and that touched me."

You only need to watch two of the Urusei Yatsura movies, the first one and this one. The first one was all Rumiko Takahashi's vision, it came out the way she envisioned it to be. Oz, heir to the Vessalius Duke House, has just turned fifteen. His life is rich and carefree, darkened only by the constant absence of his father. At his coming-of-age ceremony, everything changes. For no reason that he can discern, Oz is cast into the prison known as the "Abyss", only to be saved by a girl known as Alice, the Bloodstained Black Rabbit. The mystery there begins as Oz unravels the mystery behind Alice, the Abyss and the strange organization known as "Pandora". (Wikipedia) :)

I love Little Busters - it's typical of a Key production, filled with random moments, hilarity and emotion. The characters are adorable, the art is lovely, and the music beautiful. And, above all, it's a series about friendship.

I love Little Busters because of J.C. Staff, Key, and an english dub.
I haven't seen the show, which is kinda why I'm here. Blu-ray please! :)
Gotta love Little Busters, since it's a fine example of Jun Maeda's ability to write tragedy and of good animation quality.
You should definitely try the visual novel game of little busters! It's really good as well and another experience.
I Enjoyed Little busters more than i should, purely because of the rich storytelling layed deep within.

I love Little Busters because of the pure magic of the series. A story of childhood friends coming together to make a club and making more friends along the way. Of course like all series by Key, it's got it's scenes that make you weep.. And who couldn't love Kud. <3

I love Little Busters as it is a very well made and entertaining adaptation of the Visual Novel as well as because of all them feels that just sucker punch you straight in the heart and leave you bleeding tears.

i love little busters because it offers a great school life experience, it knows how to keep the balance between the comedy scenes and then drawn people in with the serious ones,it is something that key is very good at with their series.

I love Little Busters because it is a great, fun- filled series full of colourful characters and definitely a great additiion to the slew of slice-of-life/gakuen titles released by Key. It is filled with many hilarious moments but also comes across as genuine and downright heartwarming, there's never a dull moment and gets viewers experiencing the full range of human emotions which is what makes it such a memorable and amazing viewing experience.

For the Facebook Comp:

Little Busters was one of my first Visual Novels by Key, before Kanon, before Air and before CLANNAD, I read this one. And when I heard it was getting an anime I was ecstatic.

To see it done so well, so awesomely and however short it may be in certain aspects, just makes me so happy, I love it's plot, I love it's message about friendship that I can relate to so much, I love everything about it and wish that more people knew about it.

And really, I want to have more people appreciate this specific anime, because it gets over-shadowed by Key's other works and however more awesome they may be, Little Busters will always remain one of the best to me. Always.

I love Little Busters as it is a very well made and entertaining adaptation of the Visual Novel as well as because of all them feels that just sucker punch you straight in the heart and leave you bleeding tears.

i love little busters because it offers a great school life experience, it knows how to keep the balance between the comedy scenes and then drawn people in with the serious ones,it is something that key is very good at with their series.

I love Little Busters because it is a great, fun- filled series full of colourful characters and definitely a great additiion to the slew of slice-of-life/gakuen titles released by Key. It is filled with many hilarious moments but also comes across as genuine and downright heartwarming, there's never a dull moment and gets viewers experiencing the full range of human emotions which is what makes it such a memorable and amazing viewing experience.

For the Facebook Comp:

Little Busters was one of my first Visual Novels by Key, before Kanon, before Air and before CLANNAD, I read this one. And when I heard it was getting an anime I was ecstatic.

To see it done so well, so awesomely and however short it may be in certain aspects, just makes me so happy, I love it's plot, I love it's message about friendship that I can relate to so much, I love everything about it and wish that more people knew about it.

And really, I want to have more people appreciate this specific anime, because it gets over-shadowed by Key's other works and however more awesome they may be, Little Busters will always remain one of the best to me. Always.

Just a reminder to those that DON'T know.
Hanamonogatari takes place at the very end of the timeline.
The order (in terms of anime currently out) is as follows:
Neko(Black); Bake, Nise, Neko(White); Kabuki; Oni; Otori; Koi; Hana
SO, when Tsukimonogatari comes out, remember it will take place right after Koi.
And (if it EVER happens) Kizumonogatari would take place before Neko(Black).

Just finished this anime and....
.
.
.
.
Hot takes: While the characters are very well written, the ending is so predictable that it was a letdown.
Spoilers
.
.
.
.
.
Chisato is a great my main character, don't get me wrong. I understand her reason for refusing to kill despite being trained as an Assassin since childhood (and it wasn't her fault that she has the natural talent to be one). I love her chemistry with Takina and her (somewhat) mutual respect for Majima, they really handle it really well. I also love how they handled her when the truth finally came out to her.

But not killing her in the final episode  kind of ruined...basically all the build up they prepared themselves for the climax. Like, what was the point of giving Chisato all those problems regarding her heart if the story will end up with happy ending anyway? Chisato herself wanted her friends to move on even after her death (She even wanted Mika to keep the cafe open after her death, Takina to continue her duty as Lycoris, Mizuko to keep looking out for lover). It would be a quite bittersweet ending for them to do that. But no, the author decided to go with "Everyone's alive route", ignoring everything that they laid in the previous episode.

It's still a good anime due to Chisato carrying the series on her back, but the plot makes me put this anime into the "not worth rewatching" list, once is enough no matter how much I love Chisato.

Where is Fate/Stay Night: Fate Route remake?!!

Here's the chronological order.
[FSN= Fate Stay Night]

1. Fate Zero 

2.FSN Fate Route (by Studio Deen, old yet great.)

3.FSN Unlimited blade works (by Studio Ufotable, split in 2 seasons.)

4.FSN Heaven's Feel (by Studio Ufotable, split in 3 movies.) 

You can then watch any installment in the Fate universe in any order.

Awesome Fate/stay night Trailer.

Watch ubw first because the prequel(zero) gives major spoilers to the heaven's feel route.

The best order to watch it for an anime only is

1. Fate/Stay Night - Unlimited Blade Works
2. Fate/Stay Night - Heaven's Feel
3. Fate/Stay Night (2006) this one is optional because fans say that its a horrible adaptation
4. Fate/Zero

Then afterwards you can check out the other type-moon works
I suggest you to watch Fate/stay night 2006 first, and then this Fate/stay night Unlimited Blade Works, continue to Fate/stay night Heaven's Feel trilogy movies, and lastly Fate/Zero
Watch Fate/Zero first then UBW then Heavenâ€™s Feel. Forget about Fate/Stay Night 2006 since itâ€™s confusing and bad.

Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works (movie) is the typical Japanese adaptation. Absolute garbage. This version is supposed to be â€œFate/stay nightâ€ but focusing on Shirou (Emyia)+Rin instead of Shirou+Saber.
But it differs WILDLY from the original. A lot of liberties were taken, events changed, characters showing up where they never were, servants showing up too soon or dying b4 time, masters swapped, the 1st 25mins are a repeat of the whole â€œFate/stay nightâ€ series, then huge plot cuts, and lots of fighting to make up for the shortcomings.
Hasty, with huge jumps in time without explanation of whatâ€™s missing. Have some pride, so-called professionals of animation.
Is ULBW  is the continuation of stay night

I missed Sam Riegel as Shirou's voice from Fate/Stay Night, but I don't think I can distinguish between Kate Higgins and Kari Wahlgren! It's funny, back in 2013 at Anime Expo, I went to a Fate/Zero English dub panel where I got to ask a question to the English cast. I asked, "What is your favorite character in Fate/Zero, other than the one you played and why". The answer I got from Tony Oliver, the director, was Lancer. The why, was because he played Lancer in Fate/Stay Night and was biased towards the class.
It was funny at the time, but little did we know that 2 years later he would be reprising his role. I bet he was so glad he didn't cast himself a major role in Fate/Zero.

Awesome Owarimonogatari Trailer.
Felicia G. I suppose you might be able to, but it may be confusing as Owarimonogatari is the conclusion to the series as far as I'm aware.

+Sora Je No. This is quite literally the beginning of the end. If you wish to get into this series, start from Bakemonogatari and watch by release order:
First Season - Bakemonogatari (15 episodes), Nisemonogatari (11 Episodes), Nekomonogatari (4 episodes)
Second Season - Monogatari Series Second Season (26 episodes), Hanamonogatari (5 episodes)
Final Season - Tsukimonogatari (4 episodes), and now Owarimonogatari wich will have something around 12. And there's more to come.

+zApolloZ 
let me tell you the list of chapters of Owarimonogatari
1. Ougi Formula
2. Sodachi Riddle
3. Sodachi Lost
4. Shinobu Mail
5. Mayoi Hell
6. Hitagi Rendezvous
7. Ougi Dark


I guess you're waiting for no. 6.  keep the faith and wait.

But I guess they wont do Chapter 5-7 at the moment.  Because they were from Owarimonogatari Vol. 3 (The Owari novel was separated in 3 volumes) and they follow Koyomimonogatari.  You have to know what happened in Koyomimonogatari before these 3 chapters.  They should be doing Koyomi first before going back to Owari Vol. 3.
+Marco Polo Yes and no. He does appear in Owarimonogatari, but Owari is 3 books and this season is adapting only the first two.

+Chaotic Thinker The Anime was finished, but where's Mayoi Hell, Hitagi Rendesvouz and Ougi Dark arcs?
Will there be a Owarimonogatari part 2?
+42Caio (Caio Esteves) And the 3rd book is Zoku-Owarimonogatari?
Rei Ayanami is a whore No. Owarimonogatari has 3 volumes. Zoku Owarimonogatari is a separated entry in the series.

The first trailer I ever seen or heard of this show was on cartoon network toonami.  Greatest random blind moment ever. The fact that I was into zombies made me wanna watch it.

okay so my expectations for this season from this trailer of someone who knows absolutely nothing:

Something has caused these giant human like Gods to rise up that at first just seem harmless and just ominous but then start forming danger as they show they're no gentle giants but monsters. There is this highly specialized group of hunters that team up to protect the people from these things. But they find out they're quite smart and more dangerous than they have ever had to deal with. They lose some of their people. They try to find out where they came from. Maybe there is a greater darker hidden figure behind them, controlling or creating them.

i think the younger boy/man is the main character and goes on this cool character growth journey where he starts of in deep fear and helplessness until he finds his strength but also great loss (either someone dies, he makes a grave mistake which he feels guilty about, or he loses his sanity or humanity)

To be honest..i just wants to forget every fucking detail of this series and just watch it like a beginner 

That beginners thrill is something i wanna experience again
On a side note if you have a suggestion for me considering these 2 are my bangers, let me know. Also enjoyed stories like FMAB, Code Geass, Haikyuu.

I have good news for you. Watching it again, you'll notice details you missed on the first view. But did you know it goes even deeper than that? Think about an iceberg meme, there's the surface level, below the surface level, but there's also a BASEMENT level at the very bottoms of the ocean floor. What lies beyond the surface of the ocean, in the basement of the ocean floor? Why did Armin hold up a murex shell to Eren when they reached the sea? Is the murex shell used to make a psychedelic drug in ancient Phoenicia called the "burning purple" or the Phoenix? Why does Armin burn to death only to be born again? Why do wise old men have missing eyes or blindness in fairy tales? Why do Eren and Hanji lose their eyes? Doesn't Hanji also burn to death, and Eren in Season 1 dies and is reborn? Why did the church of the walls cover up the outside world? Why does King Fritz always look bored and out of it? Why did Ymir get titan powers when she fell into a pool of water beneath a tree and connected with a symbiote worm? Do certain trees have roots whose bark releases chemicals like dimethyltriptamine (DMT)? How is Ayahuasca prepared? Can microbes, worms, snakes, and reptiles adapt to poisonous habitats by gaining an immunity to poison through chronic micro-dosing? Did the Hallucigenia that attached to Ymir gain its powers because the tree it lived under had bark that contained DMT like acacia or mimosa root bark, which was effectively brewed into ayahuasca in the pool of murky water beneath/inside the hollow tree which Ymir fell into after being shot with an arrow? Is the main theme of Attack on Titan, "Crimson Bow and Arrow"? What is the Old English (Anglo-Saxon) word for "arrowhead" or "spearhead"? What is the etymology of the word, "God"? Did Germanic tribes dominate their continent through the use of poison tipped arrows? Did ancient Teutons have a special military unit called a berserker or a titan who fought naked? What is the origin of this symbol -> âœ or this symbol ->âš• or this symbol ->ðŸ’˜? Is Eren considered a "gadfly" and what is the origin of the word "gad"? Why did the serpent in the Garden of Eden tell Eve to eat the forbidden fruit to open her eyes? Is the forbidden fruit the fruit of her loins? What is fetal alcohol syndrome? What is auto-brewery syndrome? Is there such a thing as fetal psychedelic exposure syndrome? Is there such a thing as endogenous psychedelic overproduction syndrome? Did ancient tribes use psychedelic drugs made from snake venom to abort unwanted pregnancies? Did Eve eat her own abortion to gain enlightenment? Is this the true reason why God punishes her with "giving birth in pain" since she no longer has access to the snakes or plants in the garden that make pain-killing medicine like opium which is made from poppy seeds? Why does Christa change her name to Historia? How come Eren, Mikasa, Armin, Levi, Historia, and Erwin are orphans? How come Sasha's father (the most emotionally mature character) runs an orphanage? What is the etymology of the word, "orphan"? Does it have anything to do with the Orphic snake mysteries from ancient Greece? Is Orpheus credited with inventing a genre of literature based on substance abuse? Is the suffering and death of the god Dionysus and the hands of Titans the central myth of Orphism? Is Eren Yeager's death inspired by Dionysus? Is Jesus Christ's death inspired by Dionysus?

TLDR: Attack on Titan is real history
Crunchyroll is pretty much your only option if you're in the US.

My first Anime and the most meaningful work Iâ€™ve ever consumed was Attack on Titan. I love everything about it: The ideologies; the internal and external conflicts; the themes of hatred, freedom, trauma, redemption, sacrifice, survival, human nature and identity crisisâ€¦ Among many more. Particularly Erenâ€™s journey was probably the most tragic and impactful thing Iâ€™ve experienced. His dynamics, parallels, morality, complexity, symbolism, determination, reasons, will, consistency, worldview, dialogues, monologues, layers and his characterization in general is almost unmatched for me. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever get to experience such a thought-provoking journey ever again. And there is so much more to it than Erenâ€™s journey. There is a full cast of incredible characters with their own strengths and developmentsâ€¦ There is also an outstanding world building, amazing confrontations, many character peaks, insane plot twists and more.

Is the main theme of Attack on Titan, "Crimson Bow and Arrow"? What is the Old English (Anglo-Saxon) word for "arrowhead" or "spearhead"? What is the etymology of the word, "God"? Did Germanic tribes dominate their continent through the use of poison tipped arrows? Did ancient Teutons have a special military unit called a berserker or a titan who fought naked? What is the origin of this symbol -> âœ or this symbol ->âš• or this symbol ->ðŸ’˜? Is Eren considered a "gadfly" and what is the origin of the word "gad"? Why did the serpent in the Garden of Eden tell Eve to eat the forbidden fruit to open her eyes? Is the forbidden fruit the fruit of her loins? What is fetal alcohol syndrome? What is auto-brewery syndrome? Is there such a thing as fetal psychedelic exposure syndrome? Is there such a thing as endogenous psychedelic overproduction syndrome? Did ancient tribes use psychedelic drugs made from snake venom to abort unwanted pregnancies? Did Eve eat her own abortion to gain enlightenment? Is this the true reason why God punishes her with "giving birth in pain" since she no longer has access to the snakes or plants in the garden that make pain-killing medicine like opium which is made from poppy seeds? Why does Christa change her name to Historia? How come Eren, Mikasa, Armin, Levi, Historia, and Erwin are orphans? How come Sasha's father (the most emotionally mature character) runs an orphanage? What is the etymology of the word, "orphan"? Does it have anything to do with the Orphic snake mysteries from ancient Greece? Is Orpheus credited with inventing a genre of literature based on substance abuse? Is the suffering and death of the god Dionysus and the hands of Titans the central myth of Orphism? Is Eren Yeager's death inspired by Dionysus? Is Jesus Christ's death inspired by Dionysus?

My first Anime and the most meaningful work Iâ€™ve ever consumed was Attack on Titan. I love everything about it: The ideologies; the internal and external conflicts; the themes of hatred, freedom, trauma, redemption, sacrifice, survival, human nature and identity crisisâ€¦ Among many more. Particularly Erenâ€™s journey was probably the most tragic and impactful thing Iâ€™ve experienced. His dynamics, parallels, morality, complexity, symbolism, determination, reasons, will, consistency, worldview, dialogues, monologues, layers and his characterization in general is almost unmatched for me. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever get to experience such a thought-provoking journey ever again. And there is so much more to it than Erenâ€™s journey. There is a full cast of incredible characters with their own strengths and developmentsâ€¦ There is also an outstanding world building, amazing confrontations, many character peaks, insane plot twists and more.

I have good news for you. You don't need to erase your memory. Watching it again, you'll notice details you missed on the first view. But did you know it goes even deeper than that? Think about an iceberg meme, there's the surface level, below the surface level, but there's also a BASEMENT level at the very bottoms of the ocean floor. What lies beyond the surface of the ocean, in the basement of the ocean floor? Why did Armin hold up a murex shell to Eren when they reached the sea? Is the murex shell used to make a psychedelic drug in ancient Phoenicia called the "burning purple" or the Phoenix? Why does Armin burn to death only to be born again? Why do wise old men have missing eyes or blindness in fairy tales? Why do Eren and Hanji lose their eyes? Doesn't Hanji also burn to death, and Eren in Season 1 dies and is reborn? Why did the church of the walls cover up the outside world? Why does King Fritz always look bored and out of it? Why did Ymir get titan powers when she fell into a pool of water beneath a tree and connected with a symbiote worm? Do certain trees have roots whose bark releases chemicals like dimethyltriptamine (DMT)? How is Ayahuasca prepared? Can microbes, worms, snakes, and reptiles adapt to poisonous habitats by gaining an immunity to poison through chronic micro-dosing? Did the Hallucigenia that attached to Ymir gain its powers because the tree it lived under had bark that contained DMT like acacia or mimosa root bark, which was effectively brewed into ayahuasca in the pool of murky water beneath/inside the hollow tree which Ymir fell into after being shot with an arrow? Is the main theme of Attack on Titan, "Crimson Bow and Arrow"? What is the Old English (Anglo-Saxon) word for "arrowhead" or "spearhead"? What is the etymology of the word, "God"? Did Germanic tribes dominate their continent through the use of poison tipped arrows? Did ancient Teutons have a special military unit called a berserker or a titan who fought naked? What is the origin of this symbol -> âœ or this symbol ->âš• or this symbol ->ðŸ’˜? Is Eren considered a "gadfly" and what is the origin of the word "gad"? Why did the serpent in the Garden of Eden tell Eve to eat the forbidden fruit to open her eyes? Is the forbidden fruit the fruit of her loins? What is fetal alcohol syndrome? What is auto-brewery syndrome? Is there such a thing as fetal psychedelic exposure syndrome? Is there such a thing as endogenous psychedelic overproduction syndrome? Did ancient tribes use psychedelic drugs made from snake venom to abort unwanted pregnancies? Did Eve eat her own abortion to gain enlightenment? Is this the true reason why God punishes her with "giving birth in pain" since she no longer has access to the snakes or plants in the garden that make pain-killing medicine like opium which is made from poppy seeds? Why does Christa change her name to Historia? How come Eren, Mikasa, Armin, Levi, Historia, and Erwin are orphans? How come Sasha's father (the most emotionally mature character) runs an orphanage? What is the etymology of the word, "orphan"? Does it have anything to do with the Orphic snake mysteries from ancient Greece? Is Orpheus credited with inventing a genre of literature based on substance abuse? Is the suffering and death of the god Dionysus and the hands of Titans the central myth of Orphism? Is Eren Yeager's death inspired by Dionysus? Is Jesus Christ's death inspired by Dionysus?

TLDR: Attack on Titan is real history
From cinematic, to action, to peace, to dialog, to philosophy, to story, to even bigger story.... this truly is a masterpiece.

Something has caused these giant human like Gods to rise up that at first just seem harmless and just ominous but then start forming danger as they show they're no gentle giants but monsters. Mini Director's Commentary:
1. I planned to upload a second part because YT was only allowing this part to be copyright free, but for some reason, the next 30 seconds is copyrighted (which took the most work for this video).

2. This video was originally meant to be practice for sound design but we'll never see the rest because the 2nd part keeps getting copyrighted.

3. I have no idea how the hell Abridged YT channels get past copyright but I'm glad I never went down that route because abridged production is absolute agony.

4. I just wanted to dub over anime girls, man. But YT copyright is making me go insane.

5. Erika best girl.

- \[T]/ Solus

Zombieland Saga: Revenge!
Revenge on what though?
"This is revenge on destiny"
Oh, all right then.

The things I get from this trailer:
1. The certain bad things happen to both of Franchouchou, and Saga Prefecture itself.
2. A natural disaster happen on Saga. Judging by its damage it could be caused by an earthquake, tsunami, or a massive hurricane.
3. The audience are looks unhappy or bored with Franchouchou, you can see some of them are looking at their phones while the girls are still performing on the stage.
4. Franchouchou will have battle live concert against Iron Frill.
5. Tatsumi's plans are not going well.
6. The journalist guy try to doxx all of Franchouchou members real identity. But he only can reveal Ai, Lilly, and Junko true identity, the rest 4 still remain to be unknown because he didn't have any idea with them, since he never see them on local or national tv.
7. Ai, Lilly, and Junko true identity are revealed. And it become a big issue, and then spread into the nationwide that those 3 are getting revived in such a remote place like Saga.
8. Yuugiri's past will be revealed, but I still not sure about Tae.
9. Tae could be still remain as a zombie for almost of entire season 2. But maybe there's still a chance about she got her conscious back on the final quarter of this season  (eps. 10-12)
10. The timeline/chronology of this season is happened around the second quarter of 2019. FYI: first season timeline was set around the second-final quarter of 2018.
11. Tatsumi will tell to his zombie girls the reason why he choose, and how he bring them back from death.
.
Tbh: I still curious about the ship, and the scene where someone walking to the cliff with huge wave scene.
Can't wait zombie land saga collab with Ollie hololive.

Rewatched season 1 and i noticed smth.

>his necromancy is incomplete (tae is still acting like a zombie after all)
>he is very inexperienced in idol producing (he started in saga and always pushed the girls onto crowds with interests unrelated to idols. he always gets lucky that those crowds end up liking his idols)
>he lacks enough knowledge (he doesnt know all the details about Saga)
>he doesnt know how to talk properly with the girls thus resort back to his chuuni personality to get through them
>works tirelessly to make connections no matter how unrelated they are to idol groups in desperation of making his idols popular

Tatsumi here probably just forced himself to try and learn idol producing just so he can help Sakura achieve her dream when she was alive. He doesnt really have an interest on idols but he tries his best nonetheless out of the goodness of his heart or possible love for Sakura.

Sakura is probably the only girl that was kind to Tatsumi and the only one that called his name properly. And now he made it his life's mission to give her what she wanted despite already being dead.

BTW its possible that hes some sort of undead himself seeing that he has superhuman endurance and strength (that baseball hit deep bro. and the fact that he can kick down that barricade is saying enough. he doesnt have mental limits.)

Imma cry if this is true.

PLOT LEAK FOR SEASON 2 REVEALED:

Tsukasa has moved on with his life and has gotten technically savvy himself along with Michiru where they have both become scientists working for the betterment and improvement of Giftias.  As they work together, they find there's a way to increase the life-span of a Giftias from 9 years to 100 years.

During this research, Tsukasa and Michiru become closer.  Tsukasa is still hesitant to confess to Michiru as he fears it will interfere with their work. But Michiru has fallen head-over-heels for Tsukasa as she has observed how dedicated a man he is to both his work and in his relationships, particularly to Isla when she was still alive.
 
Then another major breakthrough discovery happens.  Tsukasa and Michiru discover that not only can they increase the life-span of a Giftia, but that it's possible to retain and transfer memories between an old Giftia at the end of its life-cycle to a new one, essentially making them immortal.  Tsukasa, realizing the implications of this, scrambles to dig through the digital archives of the lab to find all data retained for Isla.  In secret he manufacturers a physical replica of Isla.  In the meantime Michiru senses Tsukasa is up to something.

Late one night, when everyone has gone home and Tsukasa is alone, he begins to set up an attempt to transfer Isla's memories back into her new body.  Michiru suddenly appears as she was actually watching from the shadows, surprising Tsukasa.  An argument ensues and Tsukasa apologizes deeply to Michiru for being secretive as he didn't want Michiru to get in trouble as well if he was caught.  Michiru at first tells Tsukasa that such an experiment is reckless and dangerous and she wasn't going to allow it.  Michiru in her heart realizes that if Tsukasa's attempt is successful, it would most likely mean the end of her blossoming relationship with Tsukasa as she knows he still has strong feelings for Isla.  After Tsukasa explains the procedure is relatively safe and presses her for the real reason why she won't allow it, Michiru finally concedes for fear of her true feelings for Tsukasa being exposed and volunteers to stay and observe the transfer.  Even though Tsukasa told Michiru that the transfer should be relatively safe, he still feels a slight trepidation as he starts the process.

The memory transfer process begins.  Everything seems to be going well when suddenly an anomaly occurs that Michiru can only see on her computer screen.  She has it in her power to abort the memory transfer without Tsukasa knowing, making it look like a failure.  Instead tears well up in her eyes as she fixes the anomaly from her computer console without telling Tsukasa, allowing the transfer to complete.

Isla comes alive, begins to breath, and slowly opens her eyes.  Tsukasa is hesitant at first not sure if the transfer was entirely successful.  Isla then looks up, sees Tsukasa in front of her and then smiles thanking Tsukasa for the ferris wheel ride.  Tears well up in Tsukasa eyes as he is overwhelmed with joy.  He embraces Isla and they kiss. After a few moments of talking, Tsukasa remembers Michiru and turns to show Isla to her.  Michiru is gone.  He then sees something glowing on Michiru's monitor and walks over to it.  His eyes widen as the slow gentle flashes from her monitor reflect off his face as he realizes what she did. 

Michiru is walking outside away from the lab, almost stumbling, as she cries bitterly screaming out Tsukasa's name over and over.

~~~~~~~~~~

Ok just kidding, I made all that up.

"happy sugar life" these 2 are in love, 
And now, this is a spoiler
They wanted to move away because the older one (Satou) killed her best friend, so they told their aunt to burn the building, but Satou forgot her marriage ring, and they went back where they met the younger ones(Shio) brother, which wanted shio back, they ran, and in the end they there on the roof top because the stairs there looked and the building was burning really strongly now, so they decided to jump and hope to be reborn, but Satou let shio live by switching their positions, so she(Satou) would come to the floor first, so Shio didn't die, but something stayed from Shio in her soul so I think she's going to wait until a few years until the age difference matches again, but I don't really know

In fact I don't feel sorry for Satou, she may have had a tragic past but that made her a criminal. To have kidnapped a little girl who is not even her relative, to fall in love with the minor. 

She has also committed other crimes, breaking and entering (she took an apartment that was not hers). 
Murder 
Arson, which was planning with her aunt to burn down the building. 
Kidnapping 
Did she deserve to be happy after all the things she did? No! Everything bad you do even if it's for love (because honestly the love she had for Shio was almost pedophilia because she told Mitsuboshi that Shio was so pretty that Satou could hardly control herself). 
She ended up dying because that was the karma of all her crimes maybe if she had done the right thing she would still be seeing Shio.

In fact Satou was the reason why Shio is now crazy at the end. The two of them got along well because they both had mental health problems.

Why the heck NETFLIX parades this anime as ITS ORIGINAL series?!!! 
Devilman Crybaby is a 2018 Japanese original net animation  series based on Go Nagai's manga series Devilman. The web anime is directed by Masaaki Yuasa, produced by Aniplex and Dynamic Planning, animated by Science SARU. ALL JAPANESE. As in "made in Japan by the Japanese".

The only involvment Netflix has in this production is that it bought the copyright for worldwide streaming on their channel. That's it. And the Japanese are pissed that it announced it as a "Netflix original series". Rightly so.
The most overrated Devilman version to date.

Devilman
A story about Love

My parents grew up watching Mazinger Z back in the 70's, so I told them that Devilman was by the same writer and they watched it.

Anyway, I'm disowned now.

Plot Summary:Â In the year 2022, virtual reality has progressed by leaps and bounds, and a massive online role-playing game called Sword Art Online (SAO) is launched. With the aid of "NerveGear" technology, players can control their avatars within the game using nothing but their own thoughts. Kazuto Kirigaya, nicknamed "Kirito," is among the lucky few enthusiasts who get their hands on the first shipment of the game. He logs in to find himself, with ten-thousand others, in the scenic and elaborate world of Aincrad, one full of fantastic medieval weapons and gruesome monsters. However, in a cruel turn of events, the players soon realize they cannot log out; the game's creator has trapped them in his new world until they complete all one hundred levels of the game. Watching this trailer reminds me of the good old days. Before the pointless sequels that were GGO and beyond which caused SAO to lose its identity. Before Incarnation aka one of the most broken power systems came to be. When SAO had so much promise to be great or at least good. Take me back to those days. It was so simple back then. Now the show has gone so far off the rails that we have gone to Space and that the next arc is doing what is SAO's Crisis on Infinte Earths. Progressive is a thing now, but it shouldn't have been a thing. The main series should have been Progressive from the start and not whatever the show has become now. Well, at we still have trailers like this to remind us of what SAO could have been.
"The Legacy of Sword Art Online...continues."
Awesome Sword Art Online English Dub Trailer.
OHHH SO THIS IS WHERE VR DOGGO ONLINE CAME FROM

I watched SAO 2 before the first SAO because it was the only one on Netflix. I was tired of ads so I didn't use crunchyroll. I heard some good things about SAO so I started watching it. I watched it all under 24 hours. I got really connected to it and I even changed my entire PlayStation Network account to show that Simon (Shino Asada) was my favorite character. Right after I finished SAO 2 I felt empty. My life is boring all I do is watch YouTube videos, rewatch shows on Netflix and play video games. But SAO was something new. I loved it. 2 days go by after I watched SAO 2 I decide to watch the first SAO on crunchyroll. To my surprise there was an English dub version. I started watching it and like SAO 2, I finished it in less than 24 hours. That was at 6:43 PM today. Now I feel empty inside again. I can't stop thinking about SAO. I even cry thinking about SAO. I almost never cry about anything. I also tried watching SAO: Laicization but there's no English dub for it on crunchyroll so it wasn't the same. Whoever hasn't seen SAO yet, don't watch it unless your life is exciting.
fuck this dub, fuck you aniplex, fuck sword art online and fuck you papenbrook

You are right the story of my hero academia is to show you don't need power to be a hero like police and just people who help the ecosystem,you don't have to literally fight crime to be a hero you just need to be kind and do the small things that make the world a better place and that what deku wants to make everyone smile that what it means to be a hero and she doesn't need a quirk for that

The crazy thing is if Izuku was actually treating Shigiraki as a monster rather than a human (in other words more of a morally grey shaded character than the morally sunshine character we see cuz vigi Deku wasn't really him growing morally darker or more neutral by any means, just learning more about the grey shades of the society he grew up in. And Overhaul was probably the only time where we see any kind of real anger with Izuku, even with that he still just punches him into unconsciousness. Even Dark Might just got put into a nap from what we see, despite Izuku's fury at the bastardized imitation of his mentor), then I'm pretty sure Izuku outspeeds Shigiraki and blows his head off. Cuz All For One was only able to match an All might at his peak and even being rewound still took some nasty hits from Iron Might and took the L from an heavily injured Bakugo. As far as we've seen there isn't any speed quirks or such to counter gearshift overdrive, or even any perception quirks that would allow either Shigiraki or AFO to react and counter speeds faster than what the base human perception can take in much less faster than sound.

Edit: Also I'm confused about his gear breaking, I thought it acted like the one in Two Heroes where it broke if he did it at 100% 3 times? Or did it get changed for the battle? Cuz he only went at 45% which shouldnt have broken his gear if that's the case. Or is it because of fajin being added into the mix?

Persona 5's anime adaptation was bogged down by various factors, but the most important was keeping Joker in it.
Joker is not a character, he represents the player, so Persona 5 Royal's anime adaptation, which has no player, needs to rewrite the plot so that it can be done by the actual characters and doesn't include the player himself.
Other shortcomings of the anime were caused by the team's trying to keep game mechanics in it even if they aren't appropriate to the anime medium.
How this anime adaptation needs to be done to be good:

1) Joker does not exist. Haru does. Joker's traits are split between Yusuke (he got transferred from Kosei to Shujin, he assaulted Shido and attempted to murder him, he's taken by Sojiro, he enters Kamoshida's Palace alongside Ryuji, he takes Morgana at Leblanc) and Makoto (she's the leader of the Phantom Thieves, she knows Goro was behind everything). Joker's design is taken by a nameless and non-speaking recurring cameo character at Shujin whom the PTs never actually interact with.

2) Kaneshiro's arc happens before Madarame: Makoto is met earlier to "officially found" the phantom thieves. Yusuke is already following Ryuji and Morgana in Kamoshida's Palace but is a noncombatant navigator/strategist until Madarame's arc.

3) Yusuke has a new character arc, having both Madarame and Shido as nemeses. Since he was raised by Madarame, he started developing a psychological complex that made him fanatically obsessed with beauty, art, nature and purity (and also being a Shinto fundamentalist), to the point of being a sociopath with "those that do not appreciate true beauty". After seeing Shido rape the woman, he willingly attempts to kill him, calling him "an impure petty tyrant drunk with power, which only death can redeem". He's taken by Sojiro not because he's innocent, but because Sojiro knows Yusuke has a mental disorder, and he wants to take in mentally disturbed people because he feels he has failed Futaba. His two palaces have him deal with both Madarame's abuse (Madarame) and Yusuke's own sociopathy (Shido).

4) The Velvet Room appears in dreams to Yusuke and Ryuji (and later to anyone who joins the PT). No mention is made of the Wild Card, as now Yusuke is Emperor and Goro is Justice (no one is Fool). Persona Fusion and Demon Negotiation simply do not exist at all, as they would be a blatant deus-ex-machina and a one-off mechanic that is never used after the first time: every character has a Persona tied to his/her personality, including Yusuke and Makoto. Instead, Ultimate Personas appear in the plot, and Yusuke and Makoto get theirs at the same time when fighting Shido. Satanael is a third-level Persona of Makoto created when Yusuke's Kamu Susanoo is fused with Anat. The Velvet Room is seen first-person, so Yusuke never talks to the twins.

5) Social Links are replaced by various bonding scenes where parts of the Social Links of two or more characters from the game are composed into one, and more character development is given to the characters. There are episodes completely focused on those scenes. Ultimate Personas are not always granted through Social Links (see Yusuke and Makoto) but Haru and Ann get theirs in a bonding scene with each other, and Futaba in one with Yusuke.

6) Ryuji dies for real after Shido's Palace collapses. Seiten Taisei is a boss in Maruki's arc, as the true form of a Shadow guardian in Maruki's Palace that looks identical to Ryuji (as the PTs' grief for Ryuji's death is used by Maruki as a "wish he wants to grant to them"). A game can't have character deaths, but an anime can have them and they improve the story.

7) Makoto and Morgana travel to the TV station alone, rather than with Ann's class (but Ryuji and Ann follow them, while Yusuke stays home). There, Makoto and Goro start suspecting each other.

8) Maruki's arc is focused on Makoto, Goro and Kasumi. Yusuke loses focus until the Palace exploration, as he willingly goes to a psychiatric clinic for rehab (instead of a juvenile hall), then follows his game counterpart.

9) Persona fights are animated this way: the Persona stays out and damage to a persona is transmitted to the user (like Stands in JoJo). The protagonists have no weapon or gun in the real world but their Persona can transform into a weapon (a shotgun for Ryuji, a submachine gun for Ann, a katana for Yusuke, a slingshot for Morgana, a gun for Makoto, a sniper rifle for Futaba, an axe for Haru, a laser gun for Goro). Futaba's ultimate Persona Prometheus can fight, even though Necronomicon can't.

10) The title is not "Persona 5 the Animation", but "An Emperor Among Phantom Thieves", without the Persona name in it (because Persona game mechanics are taken off, it takes various liberties with the plot and it doesn't follow the game series's traditions).

11) Some characters are fully written off the plot, like Iwai (since there are no weapons), Ohya (already of minimal importance in the game), Chihaya (voice actor died and already of minimal importance in the game) and non-Yaldabaoth Igor (the voice actor died. Yaldabaoth has killed and replaced Igor, and he's replaced by Lavenza at the end, with Lavenza's fusion being actually caused by Igor's spirit). Other non-party SL are done by various party members, such as Ryuji that does Kawakami, Yusuke does Hifumi, etc. Some characters, like Caroline and Justine, exist but have their SL taken off (in the twins' case, it focuses on Fusion, which is a mechanic that cannot be adapted in Anime form).


12) Yusuke and Makoto do not receive the World Arcana. The World is Maruki's Arcana instead of the non-existing Councillor, while Kasumi is the Fool.

To those who want Joker to stay, why? 
Other than fanservice, what would Joker do if he stayed in the anime? Nothing that another character couldn't do by taking his few traits and incorporating them into his new characterization.
Remember that to make a good anime you sometimes need to take liberties from the source material. And completely writing off a silent and/or weakly characterized protagonist is the most important liberty to take, as it shows that the anime exist independent from the game and the player playing it

P5 was adapted into a fanservice-heavy trainwreck of an anime faithful to the game. P5R and subsequent games need to be adapted into good anime that break off from the game!

Giving him a personality would make for an awesome character, but cutting him completely allows other characters to take more prominent roles and split the SLs amongst the whole party, which improves characterization.

For those who may not know, this "Anime Trailer" was never a teaser for a full anime production. The JP PSX version of the game has a bonus disk which contains a bunch of extras within a menu made to look like a TV channel guide screen. This animation was made to fit that theme of a fake channel guide, as if one of the "channels" was showing this trailer. 

When EP PSX got it's US release, there was no fake channel guide, and there is a title card before the animation plays that says "Anime Trailer". The context of the fake channel guide was lost, and the title card saying "Anime Trailer" could easily be misunderstood to mean that it was supposed to be a teaser for a full production. Since this full P2 anime (which people incorrectly thought was real) never came to be, they assumed that it was just cancelled for unknown reasons.

 When you see how the animation was presented in the JP release, it's easy to realize it was never meant to be anything bigger.

We all know that this kind of awesome gritty artstyle  will never happen  even if a studio picks up Persona 2. They simply don't make anime like this anymore.

This was the most tragic part of cancelling Persona 2 anime way back when.

I have seen animes since i was a little kid in the 80', over the years i have seen many memorable ones but Violet Evergarden really touched me. Although i can understand that some people just like more action driven stuff and may find it slow and boring, it can't be everyones cup of tea. I discovered to anime maybe more than.. 10 years ago. I love anime, new or old. I havenâ€™t seen this one yet, but I canâ€™t help but be reminded of another, older anime, with a similar premise: Key, the metal idol. From what little Iâ€™ve heard of Violet Evergreen, the animeâ€™s main character is very similar to Key. Both are people, molded by the world and memories to be more machine than human. What makes Violet Evergarden so special to me â€” what makes it truly unforgettable â€” is the love story between Gilbert and Violet. Itâ€™s not your typical romance. Itâ€™s not built on passion or grand gestures. Itâ€™s Platonic in its purity, yet undeniably romantic in its quiet intensity.

Their bond is what moved me the most.
I resonate with Violet â€” her innocence, her longing, her loyalty. But you also feel Gilbert. You feel his guilt, his conflict, his quiet and steady heart burdened by a love thatâ€™s both too much and never enough. He loves her â€” probably more than anyone else ever could â€” but instead of embracing it, he chooses to walk away. Not because he doesnâ€™t care. Because he cares too much.

Gilbert deeply loves Violet, but he never tries to control her. Heâ€™s afraid of the imbalance in their relationship â€” afraid that her love stems from dependency, not understanding. That fear, combined with the weight of societal expectations and his own guilt, leads him to step away. Not out of rejection, but out of moral strength. And thatâ€™s what makes it both beautiful and tragic.

He sees her as someone too young, emotionally and mentally â€” a blank slate shaped by war. He fears her feelings were born from trauma, not true emotional maturity. To accept her love would feel, to him, like taking advantage of her innocence. Society would say:

â€œSheâ€™s too naive. Heâ€™s the adult. Itâ€™s wrong. He should know better.â€

So he tells himself:

â€œEven if I love her backâ€¦ I must protect her. Even from me.â€

And thatâ€™s the heartbreaking part.

He doesnâ€™t reject her â€” he sacrifices his own happiness, choosing to protect her from what he sees as his own shadow.
Just watching Gilbert is painful. You can feel what he feels. The terrible burden of being loved so deeply by someone who doesnâ€™t yet fully understand the world â€” and choosing pain over joy to shield them.

I deeply respect Gilbert for this. He is honorable and selfless in a way that feels almost unreachable. I wish I could be like him â€” but I donâ€™t think I could bear that kind of pain. If I were in his place, I would have accepted Violetâ€™s love. Yes, even knowing how innocent and dependent she is. But Iâ€™d help her grow. Iâ€™d be honest with her, guide her, and let her choose for herself when sheâ€™s older â€” whether to stay, or move on.

Gilbert doesnâ€™t do this because heâ€™s weak â€” but because heâ€™s strong in a different, more tragic way. He becomes the embodiment of selflessness.
He sacrifices his own happiness. He does whatâ€™s â€œright,â€ even if it breaks both of their hearts. He protects her, even when it means losing her.

Some people interpret their bond as father-daughter â€” that Gilbert was a guardian, not a romantic figure. That he was merely there to guide Violet, help her grow, and then disappear so she could become her own person. And sure, that interpretation exists. It focuses on:The age and power gap, Violetâ€™s emotional immaturity, and Gilbertâ€™s guilt as the reason he walks away.

But the truth is thatâ€™s not the whole story. The anime and the light novels make it very clear â€” this is not just a parental bond. Violetâ€™s love is romantic. She doesnâ€™t vaguely say â€œI love youâ€ â€” she yearns for him.

Gilbertâ€™s silence is not because he sees her as a child â€” itâ€™s because he doesnâ€™t believe he deserves her love. His absence isnâ€™t an act of guardianship. Itâ€™s a self-imposed exile â€” driven by shame, not detachment.

And as the Violet Evergarden Gaiden and the final movie show us, their feelings are mutual. Violet grows. She learns. She becomes someone who chooses to love â€” not because she was trained to, but because she wants to. She discovers that Gilbert is alive, living in isolation on a remote island, teaching children â€” ashamed of his past and convinced heâ€™s unworthy of her.

But she finds him.
She confronts him. She cries. She tells him:

â€œI love you.â€
â€œIâ€™m not a tool. Iâ€™m Violet Evergarden.â€

This moment â€” this declaration â€” is everything. Itâ€™s not a childâ€™s plea. Itâ€™s a grown woman making a choice.
Gilbert, once again, tries to resist. He tells her she deserves more. That she should move on. But she refuses. She tells him she wants to build a life with him. That her love isnâ€™t naive anymore â€” itâ€™s mature, intentional, real.

And finallyâ€¦ he accepts it.

The movie ends with them walking hand-in-hand into the future, on that same island. Itâ€™s not a dramatic, showy reunion. Itâ€™s quiet. Gentle. Deeply emotional. Just like them.

Kana Akatsuki (the original author) and Kyoto Animation both leaned into this as a romantic conclusion. In interviews, the director even said: 

â€œWe chose not to show a kiss scene because Violetâ€™s emotions are more than physical. The point was not to show romance, but to show connection.â€

Their love is a connection that runs deeper than labels, deeper than age, and deeper than words. Violet is no longer a girl. Sheâ€™s someone who understands who she is. And Gilbert finally lets go of the guilt, opening his heart and allowing himself to love â€” and be loved â€” without fear.

Their love story is not ordinary. Itâ€™s not explosive. Itâ€™s quiet. But itâ€™s also one of the most emotionally powerful, morally complex, and deeply moving love stories Iâ€™ve ever seen in my life. I hope you can understand.

Spoiler for the ending:

I distinctly remember the ending stressing me and having me on the edge of my seat more than any horror or action film ever could. If you watch the movie in isolation, you probably wouldn't have the same feeling, but having seen Violet's growth throughout the years, and seeing her resolution in the last episode of the series, you understand it is likely and even beautiful in its own way if Violet had truly went her own way instead of being with Gilbert. The fact that Violet DID walk away first solidified it. Yet, as a last bit of fantastical magic left in this age that is slowly shifting toward modern technology, her heartfelt wish was answered. They managed a classical fairy tale ending and to be able to do something that have been done over and over so well is a feat that only Kyoani can manage.
The ultimate work of art about human emotions. Are you interested?! Are there any sincere people like Violet in life?

Spoiler for the ending:

I distinctly remember the ending stressing me and having me on the edge of my seat more than any horror or action film ever could. If you watch the movie in isolation, you probably wouldn't have the same feeling, but having seen Violet's growth throughout the years, and seeing her resolution in the last episode of the series, you understand it is likely and even beautiful in its own way if Violet had truly went her own way instead of being with Gilbert. The fact that Violet DID walk away first solidified it. Yet, as a last bit of fantastical magic left in this age that is slowly shifting toward modern technology, her heartfelt wish was answered. They managed a classical fairy tale ending and to be able to do something that have been done over and over so well is a feat that only Kyoani can manage.
The ultimate work of art about human emotions. Are you interested?! Are there any sincere people like Violet in life?

What makes Violet Evergarden so special to me â€” what makes it truly unforgettable â€” is the love story between Gilbert and Violet. Itâ€™s not your typical romance. Itâ€™s not built on passion or grand gestures. Itâ€™s Platonic in its purity, yet undeniably romantic in its quiet intensity.

Their bond is what moved me the most.
I resonate with Violet â€” her innocence, her longing, her loyalty. But you also feel Gilbert. You feel his guilt, his conflict, his quiet and steady heart burdened by a love thatâ€™s both too much and never enough. He loves her â€” probably more than anyone else ever could â€” but instead of embracing it, he chooses to walk away. Not because he doesnâ€™t care. Because he cares too much.

Gilbert deeply loves Violet, but he never tries to control her. Heâ€™s afraid of the imbalance in their relationship â€” afraid that her love stems from dependency, not understanding. That fear, combined with the weight of societal expectations and his own guilt, leads him to step away. Not out of rejection, but out of moral strength. And thatâ€™s what makes it both beautiful and tragic.

He sees her as someone too young, emotionally and mentally â€” a blank slate shaped by war. He fears her feelings were born from trauma, not true emotional maturity. To accept her love would feel, to him, like taking advantage of her innocence. Society would say:

â€œSheâ€™s too naive. Heâ€™s the adult. Itâ€™s wrong. He should know better.â€

So he tells himself:

â€œEven if I love her backâ€¦ I must protect her. Even from me.â€

And thatâ€™s the heartbreaking part.

He doesnâ€™t reject her â€” he sacrifices his own happiness, choosing to protect her from what he sees as his own shadow.
Just watching Gilbert is painful. You can feel what he feels. The terrible burden of being loved so deeply by someone who doesnâ€™t yet fully understand the world â€” and choosing pain over joy to shield them.

I deeply respect Gilbert for this. He is honorable and selfless in a way that feels almost unreachable. I wish I could be like him â€” but I donâ€™t think I could bear that kind of pain. If I were in his place, I would have accepted Violetâ€™s love. Yes, even knowing how innocent and dependent she is. But Iâ€™d help her grow. Iâ€™d be honest with her, guide her, and let her choose for herself when sheâ€™s older â€” whether to stay, or move on.

Gilbert doesnâ€™t do this because heâ€™s weak â€” but because heâ€™s strong in a different, more tragic way. He becomes the embodiment of selflessness.
He sacrifices his own happiness. He does whatâ€™s â€œright,â€ even if it breaks both of their hearts. He protects her, even when it means losing her.

Some people interpret their bond as father-daughter â€” that Gilbert was a guardian, not a romantic figure. That he was merely there to guide Violet, help her grow, and then disappear so she could become her own person. And sure, that interpretation exists. It focuses on:The age and power gap, Violetâ€™s emotional immaturity, and Gilbertâ€™s guilt as the reason he walks away.

But the truth is thatâ€™s not the whole story. The anime and the light novels make it very clear â€” this is not just a parental bond. Violetâ€™s love is romantic. She doesnâ€™t vaguely say â€œI love youâ€ â€” she yearns for him.

Gilbertâ€™s silence is not because he sees her as a child â€” itâ€™s because he doesnâ€™t believe he deserves her love. His absence isnâ€™t an act of guardianship. Itâ€™s a self-imposed exile â€” driven by shame, not detachment.

And as the Violet Evergarden Gaiden and the final movie show us, their feelings are mutual. Violet grows. She learns. She becomes someone who chooses to love â€” not because she was trained to, but because she wants to. She discovers that Gilbert is alive, living in isolation on a remote island, teaching children â€” ashamed of his past and convinced heâ€™s unworthy of her.

But she finds him.
She confronts him. She cries. She tells him:

â€œI love you.â€
â€œIâ€™m not a tool. Iâ€™m Violet Evergarden.â€

This moment â€” this declaration â€” is everything. Itâ€™s not a childâ€™s plea. Itâ€™s a grown woman making a choice.
Gilbert, once again, tries to resist. He tells her she deserves more. That she should move on. But she refuses. She tells him she wants to build a life with him. That her love isnâ€™t naive anymore â€” itâ€™s mature, intentional, real.

And finallyâ€¦ he accepts it.

The movie ends with them walking hand-in-hand into the future, on that same island. Itâ€™s not a dramatic, showy reunion. Itâ€™s quiet. Gentle. Deeply emotional. Just like them.

Kana Akatsuki (the original author) and Kyoto Animation both leaned into this as a romantic conclusion. In interviews, the director even said: 

â€œWe chose not to show a kiss scene because Violetâ€™s emotions are more than physical. The point was not to show romance, but to show connection.â€

Their love is a connection that runs deeper than labels, deeper than age, and deeper than words. Violet is no longer a girl. Sheâ€™s someone who understands who she is. And Gilbert finally lets go of the guilt, opening his heart and allowing himself to love â€” and be loved â€” without fear.

Their love story is not ordinary. Itâ€™s not explosive. Itâ€™s quiet. But itâ€™s also one of the most emotionally powerful, morally complex, and deeply moving love stories Iâ€™ve ever seen in my life. I hope you can understand.

Dear A â€“ 1 picture and Mr. Naoshi Arakawa
Over this week, I watched the Your lie in April for the first time and I could get my mind out of the Sad ending, which Kaori did not pass the surgery. The ending is beautiful and emotional but it was hurt every time I watched it again. Kaori rises Kousei rescue him from the past, she gave him hope and another chance to play the piano. Despite the fact she had been sick for a long time and could not live any longer but she still tries to save Kousei live. 
I read a lot of Happy ending on Wattpad and it raise my feeling a little bit but there is something still hurt my mind likes Kousei will be left alone again with his feelings just like my childhood, which makes me have a courage to do this. I am begging A -1 pictures and Mr. Naoshi Arakawa, please make a Happy ending for both Arima Kousei and Miyanoro Kaori. I always imaged Kousei walk into the hospital after the performance and see Kaori resting after her success surgery and after that maybe they can marry or even have kids. And I know it is hard and take time, money and efforts.
But those two should live happy after all like Kousei talked in episode 8 Light of life: â€œI am going on a journey. Searching for that moment. When my music reaches someone amides wild applause. Search for that image of you. Until one day when we can walk together shoulder to shoulder.â€ This anime saved me from a lonely boy loves Oreo have issues in trust people and usually alone to a boy think that I should try to trust people more and enjoy every moment in life. I wish I had a friend like Kaori. 
I am sorry for the long letter. Thank you for reading all of this. I do not have email of Mr. Naoshi Arakawa, which I wish I had and could to him more, so I have to send in this. Please give me hope like Miyazono Kaori did.
Thank you.
Arigato.

Ever since his mother died, Kousei Arima stopped playing music. But that's about to change when he meets a free spirited violinist, Kaori Miyazono. Will Kousei find his true calling, or be consumed by grief?

This anime needs to have a rhythm game for PS4, Xbox One, Switch, and PC with these key features:
- Developed by iNiS and published by Bandai Namco, who made Elite Beat Agents as well
- Have a special wireless piano controller that is optional for playing the game
- Create your own character, as well as customize Kousei and Kaori to your liking
- Have a hub world based on the anime's main city
- Have a career mode based on the anime's story
- Have both local and online multiplayer
- Have note calibration in the settings menu if they seem to be out of sync with the video
- Have MIDI support for using a real digital piano to play the game with
- Could be called Piano of Reason or Piano of Friction

(Spoilers Review)
I just finished my marathon of this show, it took 2 days to watch 22 episodes. So, there I was late at night looking for my next Anime to watch, when I stumbled across â€œYour Lie in Aprilâ€ all the comments were giving out great reviews on it, so I decided to give it a go. And I have to say, it was good. I enjoyed it very much, the characters, the plot and the music were all good. But I must be honest in my review, and I think this show is a little bit overrated, and in fact there are some things about this show that I really didnâ€™t like. Just because the plot of this Anime is tragic, and one of your main characters is going to die at the end, does not automatically mean itâ€™s a masterpiece of an Anime. Just because the girl dying is the clichÃ© â€œfree spiritâ€ character who teachers the broken boy how to feel again, does not mean itâ€™s destined to make you cry. I honestly tried to let myself get lost in this Anime, so I could feel it better, and some part of me did. But I was never fully into it. And I think what gets me the most is just how unsatisfying it was, like seriously, very unsatisfying. For being a love story, this Anime has zero romance, there is no kissing, hugging or any physical interaction at all (besides piggybacks) and even verbally there is not much to go on. Kaori is clearly in love with Kousei, but you must wait until she dies, just so she can write it in a letter. And Kousei clearly loves Kaori, but he will only think it in his mind and never tell her outload. Neither of them ever tells the other, in person, that they love them. And Tsubaki is a total third wheel character, Kousei never has any romantic feelings for her and even when she tells him to â€˜love her insteadâ€™ he kind of just shrugs it off like nothing. Heâ€™s so hopelessly in love with Kaori that thereâ€™s really no room for Tsubaki. And even at the end of the series it almost feels like a forced relationship between them, because you know sheâ€™s never going to be able to fill the hole Kaori left. And he never even gave her any romantic signs, itâ€™s just weird. But the worst character of them all was Nagi Aiza. She becomes Kouseiâ€™s apprentice, but honestly, no one gives a shit about her. She takes up 2-3 episodes of character development, at a crucial time when Kaori is in hospital DYING. And itâ€™s just like â€œI donâ€™t give a shit about this character right now, show me Kousei & Kaori interacting at the hospital, they have so much to discussâ€ But nope, 22 episodes in this series, and 2-3 of them are wasted on Nagi, a character I will never care about. Anyway, I thought the final episode was nice, the way Kousei played the piano to her while she was being operated on, then she appeared in his vision and played alongside him, a beautiful final goodbye. And I guess it fit in the whole â€œspeak through music to each otherâ€ theme of the show. It was a nice scene, but at the same time I wished they had a proper last visit with each other, in person, and confessed how they felt to one-another. Because the next scene after his performance was a skip to her funeral and I was kind of just like â€œWhat? Really sheâ€™s dead just like that?â€ I just wished they had talked more. All-in-all though it was a good Anime, personally I found it kind of unsatisfying, but still good. I recommend to most people. The music is good too, some of it is a little bit long though, and drags on, but most of it is good. It was a great, sad anime, but itâ€™s not a masterpiece like most people claim. That is my honest opinion. 

Thanks for the memories â€œYour Lie in Aprilâ€ it was a fun ride, sad, but fun. Until we meet again

There's only one word to describe this anime: exquisite.  When I first started to watch anime this was the first I watched and little did I know it would take me on a journey to another land. It opened my eyes to see what the world was like.  I can say,  in my first year, middle school, I met a boy under a full grown willow tree and my fate has begun to change.  Allowing me to fall in love.  I realize how much people take for granted now we only realize how much we love someone until after they're gone. I met this person only two years after and never thought we would ever become friends but as fate has it,  we did.  Then came 7th grade and we drifted.  I made a promise to myself to no matter what always love him until I graduate.  I've kept this promise every single day.  Your lie in April,  thank you for helping me love.

Dear A â€“ 1 picture and Mr. Naoshi Arakawa
Over this week, I watched the Your lie in April for the first time and I could get my mind out of the Sad ending, which Kaori did not pass the surgery. The ending is beautiful and emotional but it was hurt every time I watched it again. Kaori rises Kousei rescue him from the past, she gave him hope and another chance to play the piano. Despite the fact she had been sick for a long time and could not live any longer but she still tries to save Kousei live. 
I read a lot of Happy ending on Wattpad and it raise my feeling a little bit but there is something still hurt my mind likes Kousei will be left alone again with his feelings just like my childhood, which makes me have a courage to do this. I am begging A -1 pictures and Mr. Naoshi Arakawa, please make a Happy ending for both Arima Kousei and Miyanoro Kaori. I always imaged Kousei walk into the hospital after the performance and see Kaori resting after her success surgery and after that maybe they can marry or even have kids. And I know it is hard and take time, money and efforts.
But those two should live happy after all like Kousei talked in episode 8 Light of life: â€œI am going on a journey. Searching for that moment. When my music reaches someone amides wild applause. Search for that image of you. Until one day when we can walk together shoulder to shoulder.â€ This anime saved me from a lonely boy loves Oreo have issues in trust people and usually alone to a boy think that I should try to trust people more and enjoy every moment in life. I wish I had a friend like Kaori. 
I am sorry for the long letter. Thank you for reading all of this. I do not have email of Mr. Naoshi Arakawa, which I wish I had and could to him more, so I have to send in this. Please give me hope like Miyazono Kaori did.
Thank you.
Arigato.
