(Spoilers Review)
I just finished my marathon of this show, it took 2 days to watch 22 episodes. So, there I was late at night looking for my next Anime to watch, when I stumbled across â€œYour Lie in Aprilâ€ all the comments were giving out great reviews on it, so I decided to give it a go. And I have to say, it was good. I enjoyed it very much, the characters, the plot and the music were all good. But I must be honest in my review, and I think this show is a little bit overrated, and in fact there are some things about this show that I really didnâ€™t like. Just because the plot of this Anime is tragic, and one of your main characters is going to die at the end, does not automatically mean itâ€™s a masterpiece of an Anime. Just because the girl dying is the clichÃ© â€œfree spiritâ€ character who teachers the broken boy how to feel again, does not mean itâ€™s destined to make you cry. I honestly tried to let myself get lost in this Anime, so I could feel it better, and some part of me did. But I was never fully into it. And I think what gets me the most is just how unsatisfying it was, like seriously, very unsatisfying. For being a love story, this Anime has zero romance, there is no kissing, hugging or any physical interaction at all (besides piggybacks) and even verbally there is not much to go on. Kaori is clearly in love with Kousei, but you must wait until she dies, just so she can write it in a letter. And Kousei clearly loves Kaori, but he will only think it in his mind and never tell her outload. Neither of them ever tells the other, in person, that they love them. And Tsubaki is a total third wheel character, Kousei never has any romantic feelings for her and even when she tells him to â€˜love her insteadâ€™ he kind of just shrugs it off like nothing. Heâ€™s so hopelessly in love with Kaori that thereâ€™s really no room for Tsubaki. And even at the end of the series it almost feels like a forced relationship between them, because you know sheâ€™s never going to be able to fill the hole Kaori left. And he never even gave her any romantic signs, itâ€™s just weird. But the worst character of them all was Nagi Aiza. She becomes Kouseiâ€™s apprentice, but honestly, no one gives a shit about her. She takes up 2-3 episodes of character development, at a crucial time when Kaori is in hospital DYING. And itâ€™s just like â€œI donâ€™t give a shit about this character right now, show me Kousei & Kaori interacting at the hospital, they have so much to discussâ€ But nope, 22 episodes in this series, and 2-3 of them are wasted on Nagi, a character I will never care about. Anyway, I thought the final episode was nice, the way Kousei played the piano to her while she was being operated on, then she appeared in his vision and played alongside him, a beautiful final goodbye. And I guess it fit in the whole â€œspeak through music to each otherâ€ theme of the show. It was a nice scene, but at the same time I wished they had a proper last visit with each other, in person, and confessed how they felt to one-another. Because the next scene after his performance was a skip to her funeral and I was kind of just like â€œWhat? Really sheâ€™s dead just like that?â€ I just wished they had talked more. All-in-all though it was a good Anime, personally I found it kind of unsatisfying, but still good. I recommend to most people. The music is good too, some of it is a little bit long though, and drags on, but most of it is good. It was a great, sad anime, but itâ€™s not a masterpiece like most people claim. That is my honest opinion. 

Thanks for the memories â€œYour Lie in Aprilâ€ it was a fun ride, sad, but fun. Until we meet again

Digimon has been a big part of my life for 20 plus years...I'm 28 now snd I've always like Digimon better than pokemon.. after thr first season when they all get off  the train back home and the Digimon are running waving goodbye while "hey Digimon, hey Digimon" plays I remember crying like a baby and I just rewatched first season(cried again at the end)  and 2 season(got me in thr feels big time ) and the tri movies (making me feel grown and sad) and idk if I can watch this and say goodbye to the characters I've loved all these years. to some people it's a cartoon but when you grow up in a broken home with no friends these characters become something more than a "cartoon". I'll miss them. can't believe I'm almost 30 when it seems like yesterday I had my digivice feeding my koromon... thanks Digimon for everything.

It's not supposed to expand on the previous film, that would be a repetitive mechanic because Last Evolution Kizuna and The Beginning are two different movies with very different themes as well. Also the final frame of Last Evolution Kizuna after the credits is the answer to how Tai and the other original digidestined will recover their digimons. It's all about Tai Thesis about humans and digimons which is connected to his future job as we see in 02 Epilogue.  Somehow Tai in the future can find a way (after all Digimon are data).
Personally i prefer Adventure 01 movie and Adventure 02 movie having their own story. This movie can be very underwhelming for many fans but it's heavy plot once again about relationships, humans and digimons in a different and twisted way . That's the core of the franchise. New challenges and new conflicts and perspectives.
So it was Digimon Tamers back then. Even Adventure 02 had some bits even not in a level like The Beginning.
Remake Adventure 3 and I might actually cry

I actually enjoyed the movie despite the negative hype. It's best if people watch the film without thinking much about previous movies and shows. I mean most recent digimon media often tries to rehash previous stories and relies on nostalgia. While not action-heavy, most of the scenes left much more of an impact with their tone, voice acting, and musical score. And unlike past entries, it doesn't actually contradict any existing plot elements and even addresses the conception that most digimon seem to be just reflections of their human partners. The ending was also much better than the previous ones.

I think its the Animax dub. The Animax dub is the only dub in existence for the uncut version of Cardcaptor Sakura
@Luna Ruiz It was confirmed that the Animax dub is on the Netflix airings of Cardcaptor Sakura, so you're correct

The English subtitles' translation for this Blu-Ray are inaccurate. It's a downgrade from Rika Takahashi's translation that was on the Pioneer/Geneon DVD releases, which I got so used to I'd have to autocorrect the Blu-Ray's subtitles in my head every time, like when Sakura would say "Oni-chan!" but the subs reads "Toya!", or when Sakura addresses Shaoran with his last name with "Li-Kun!" but the subs indicates his first name. This is critical for the plot, aa she does not call him by his first name until near the end of the series, which is a milestone acknowledgement that she's closer to him than when they first met as rivals. I'm hoping the standard edition that was just released was updated but I wouldn't be surprised if it isn't.
The first dub caught me off guard in all honesty. Sakura is a ten year old elementary school student so having a voice that sounded like a teenager was really off.

I just finished my marathon of this show, for the second time, and I have the following to say (Spoilers) 
What a great, yet disappointing, show this was. I watched the first season In 2020 and liked it very much, would've recommended it to anyone. But then I re-watched it this year, in 2021 (including season 2 this time) and the first season was still good, but the second season was absolute trash, and really put a damper on the whole show. I'm not sure if I would recommended it to people now. If I had the summarize the show I'd do it in two parts. 

SEASON 1: 
Amazing, I really enjoyed it and would recommend to anyone looking for something new and exciting to watch. The three main characters are great, and each of them brings something new to the table. Norman is basically the boy prodigy, the best of all the children, and seems to be the 'man with the plan' for most of season 1. Ray seems to be just as smart as Norman (maybe) but darker and more suspicious of people, he's a very pessimistic character and he brings that vibe to the group, which is a good layer to the series. I get the impression Emma doesn't quite have the IQ of her male counterparts, but is physically superior, and has more compassion and empathy for people. She is the main character of the series and the driving force behind most of the groups plans. It's a really good dynamic and the three complement each other nicely. Season 1 is done really well, the thrill and suspense of the show was done superbly. And Isabella was great at the 'mother' figure of the household. When you realise she is actually the enemy it really gives off a sense of creepiness that I haven't seen in many Animes before. The other children were okay also, but kinda annoying, I was really only there for the main three. You almost feel hopeless when Norman is taken away, and Emma & Ray slip into depression, but then the 180 they do, to escape, is amazing. Great season, great ending, I really enjoyed it and give it a 8/10.

SEASON 2:
Terrible, I did not enjoy it at all. I'm not sure if there were budget cuts, writers strike, or some sort of production issues while making season 2, but something went wrong. Rushed doesn't even describe how forced the plot was in season 2, apparently they cut out like 150 chapters of the manga, and thought it was for the best. Everything about it was horrible. Emma became annoying, she was this over the top optimistic character that basically just kept repeating 'I wanna save everyone' or 'I don't wanna kill he demons' I get that's her thing, but it was too much and it just became annoying. Ray completely devolved as a character, it's like the writers didn't know what to do with him, he had no purpose, he was kind of just floating around, and his character felt very forced. Like, in season 1 he was the one suggesting leaving all the sibling behind because they were a burden to escape with, yet in season 2 he's agreeing with Emma that killing the demons is wrong, his character just felt off. And I don't even know wtf was going on with Norman in season 2. All the characters just imploded on themselves and nothing really made sense. In season 1 they spend all their time trying to escape a house, and climb over a wall, that was their mission. Yet in season 2 Norman is developing chemical weapons to shoot missiles into a town of demons and kill them, and Emma & Ray have mastered hunting and archery in a couple days. It was just way too forced, not to mention everything they needed for the plot just fell into their laps. Like finding a multi-million dollar complex that has electricity and hot water, just waiting for them. Or it just so happens that the one blind demon who is hanging around them has the cure in his blood for all demons, and his holding a microchip for the kids that not only gives them the blue-print of the bad guys layer, but also gives them the cure to Normans sickness (which you never see him develop) there's probably thousands of demons out there, and the one demon who's basically sharing an apartment with them is the one they need, how lucky. Every emotional moment in season 2 felt like nothing to me, it was so poorly done that I felt dead inside. Every time a character cried, I would look at the clock and wish I was doing something else, it was just bad. there were so many more problems but the end story is that everything in season 2 was bad. I'm not surprised this show didn't get a season 3. I give it a 2/10

CONCLUSION: 
Season 1 was great, go watch it. Season 2 was terrible, don't watch it. 

Thank you for the memories 'The Promised Neverland' it was an experience. I would say 'until we meet again' but I honestly don't want to...
Cya.

Why we havenâ€™t gotten a second season is an utter travesty. I loved the god of high school season one.

If you're here wondering if you should watch it, I'd recommend it. :) Just finished it and the thing that's good to understand is this: It's basically a shonen that normally would take a few hundred episodes with the character development, story and world building, condensed into 13 episodes. If this is your first shonen, go watch a different one then come back to this. For the rest of you - you know how this plays out and how things go down, so thank the series for not wasting your time and enjoy the ride :).
If a second season of GoH ever gets announced, I hope MAPPA give the animation budget the same treatment like they did with Chainsaw Man and Jujutsu Kaisen.

Thanks to producer park sung hoo and all the others that took part in the anime!
As for me(a Korean fan of both the webtoon and anime), I think the anime was a considerable success, good start for a webtoon original anime(just my opinion). I've actually been a bit disappointed by the ToG(tower of god-don't know the capitals sorry)cause it seemed they changed a lot from the original plot and story. But the GoH didn't seem to change a lot from the original story, and had extreme quality, so I felt it was worth to watch. Also, the extreme action scenes meant they had put a lot of effort and work in it, and that felt satisfying too.(the key point why i think it's better than toG)I know it's frustrating they had to put more than 100 chapters in this one anime; but you could see in the anime that they tried to show the main setups you need to understand the story. These could only be my opinion, but I've seen many korean fans agreeing to this. Regardless of the advantage/disadvantage of the anime, I wanna give a thumbs-up to the production crew for such a great anime producing. Thanks for the hard work!!

Thanks to producer park sung hoo and all the others that took part in the anime!
As for me(a Korean fan of both the webtoon and anime), I think the anime was a considerable success, good start for a webtoon original anime(just my opinion). I've actually been a bit disappointed by the ToG(tower of god-don't know the capitals sorry)cause it seemed they changed a lot from the original plot and story. But the GoH didn't seem to change a lot from the original story, and had extreme quality, so I felt it was worth to watch. Also, the extreme action scenes meant they had put a lot of effort and work in it, and that felt satisfying too.(the key point why i think it's better than toG)I know it's frustrating they had to put more than 100 chapters in this one anime; but you could see in the anime that they tried to show the main setups you need to understand the story. These could only be my opinion, but I've seen many korean fans agreeing to this. Regardless of the advantage/disadvantage of the anime, I wanna give a thumbs-up to the production crew for such a great anime producing. Thanks for the hard work!!

This stands the test of time. I've reread TGOH 5 time in the time it was waiting for an anime. Reading until the end, enjoying the characters and story development that I always yearned for in story that step into interesting fields of story-telling, this Anime OP brought that to me. I won't batter the anime Crunchyroll gave us, but I am upset. I know a lot of readers of the Webtoon carry the same sentiment, and I wish we could unite like the day we waited for a new installment of the Webtoon that always made us come back. From Commissioner Q, Mori Hui, Mori Dan, Dean, Ox King,  Beak, Ilpyo, Jin and Jang, Alexandros, and Gramps Teagin. These characters had so much to love for, from the simpliest of actions. I hope that some day, artist and writer could give us another Webtoon that surpasses what modern day anime  have yet to call  our attention on, and if you found it, the best to you! God of High is genuinely a masterpiece of world bring entertainment that makes me want to indulge into the world it created.
Real OGs are still this wasnâ€™t the official OP. Waited so long for such a downgrade

Just finished it. What a banger! Unique animated action and art style, thought provoking themes including talent vs. hardwork, rich symbolism, and characters that contrast and compliment each other's personalities well. Smile is like a robot that never smiles, while Peco is energetic and dreams to be the world champion. Ping pong is a reflection of the characters' growth and realistic journeys through life. Here comes the hero.

I didnâ€™t read ping pong before the animation, but Iâ€™ve scan through Taiyouâ€™s works before and since everybody raved about it back in 2014, I read the comic. It was great, but I realised how would they adapt it onto moving pictures, this very unique, surrealist art? Many artist works have lost its soul being adapted before. Kozue for example got 2 adaptions and while one is beautiful the other is bland, the beautiful one did not manage to transfer the richly detail and wondrous scenery she crafted. Then, this came along and destroy any excuses the studios had. This embody Taiyouâ€™s style so well, I thought I was reading the comic, in the best way possible. The incredible miracle that is Ping Pong the animation brought those wonderful memories of the mid to late 90s when Japanese animation is at the forefront of fringe culture, completely free, driven by experimentation and passion alone producing mind melting works that influence the early 2000s. Itâ€™s not the moe, harem, isekai, whatever the popular trash can money making genre is that made Japanese culture become a cult in the West, itâ€™s the imaginative cyberpunk, the stylistic and beautiful arts in sport comics like this and Inoue that cemented Japan place in the world. The torch bearer like Yukimura of Vinland and Haruko of Hoseki no Kuni will hopefully keep the tradition alive and well in the face of trash mass market.

i dont understand people that dislike this shows animation, its unconventionally weird and communicates the weirdness and fluidness of real life motion. Just finished it. What a banger! Unique animated action and art style, thought provoking themes including talent vs. hardwork, rich symbolism, and characters that contrast and compliment each other's personalities well. Smile is like a robot that never smiles, while Peco is energetic and dreams to be the world champion. Ping pong is a reflection of the characters' growth and realistic journeys through life. Here comes the hero.

I didnâ€™t read ping pong before the animation, but Iâ€™ve scan through Taiyouâ€™s works before and since everybody raved about it back in 2014, I read the comic. It was great, but I realised how would they adapt it onto moving pictures, this very unique, surrealist art? Many artist works have lost its soul being adapted before. Kozue for example got 2 adaptions and while one is beautiful the other is bland, the beautiful one did not manage to transfer the richly detail and wondrous scenery she crafted. Then, this came along and destroy any excuses the studios had. This embody Taiyouâ€™s style so well, I thought I was reading the comic, in the best way possible. The incredible miracle that is Ping Pong the animation brought those wonderful memories of the mid to late 90s when Japanese animation is at the forefront of fringe culture, completely free, driven by experimentation and passion alone producing mind melting works that influence the early 2000s. Itâ€™s not the moe, harem, isekai, whatever the popular trash can money making genre is that made Japanese culture become a cult in the West, itâ€™s the imaginative cyberpunk, the stylistic and beautiful arts in sport comics like this and Inoue that cemented Japan place in the world. The torch bearer like Yukimura of Vinland and Haruko of Hoseki no Kuni will hopefully keep the tradition alive and well in the face of trash mass market.

The anime starts with her buying a Wonder Egg. That's where the name comes from.
They should never have tried to actually explain the Wonder Egg dream world, it should have just been used as a vehicle in which the characters could explore the various themes of the show.

â€‹@yanek_vAi also decided to literally leave her other 2 friends behind who were clear struggling and needed support. Which completely betrays the themes of the show and what the set up in the first 7 episode. Ai literally forgot everything she learned and left friend who clearly needed her. The show message was not clear at all, it kept on changing it's goal and coming up with bs sci-fi plot points to explain things we didn't need to know. The idea of moving on is fine but you can do that together well helping each other, something we she foreshadowed early on. It would have made perfect sense for Ai to stay with her friends who need the emotional support since they felt like they lost everything, guess what they did. Since Ai left them in the dust, to chase the friend she seemed to care about the least. Wonder Egg is a show I'm ever passionate about anf wrote a whole essay long review on it. The ending is one of the worst of all time as it not only does not go with the easy ending it has been setting up, but adds a lot more bs plot points last minute that were not needed. Your point are technically wrong but they paint the whole picture are you didn't mention the fact that Ai literally left girls with suicide tendencies to wallow in there own sorrows and not help them after she came to her own realization about herself and this whole thing. Like help them out. It's complete character assassination

This is mostly a good trailer but there is one major issue with it. Not a single line from Ed. This trailer makes it seem like Roy is the main character. It is a shame because the start was perfect. The start has a scene from Hughes that talks about "the boys" and making them a state alchemist, mentioning the millitarry and talking about how they will go through hell. This is all great and sets up the audience to know who Ed and Al are from a out of context clip, perfect for a trailer. But then it doesn't have a single line from Ed and has only a few actions shots of him, all of which come from the intros. 

This is supposed to be constructive critisism because the rest of the trailer is perfect, I just think you should re-edit it to have more of a focus on Ed and Al's journey and less about Roy.

I just finished my marathon of FMA & FMAB and I have to say the followingâ€¦(Spoilers) 
I had watched the first episode of both series once before in the past, but they didnâ€™t hook me in enough to stay. This time I decided to give it a proper go and watch more than one episode and I have to say, it was good. I was unsure which one to watch first, so I went in chronological order, FMA then FMAB. Once I finished the original series of 04, I was reasonably impressed, I liked the characters, animation and even the story telling. Though some things didnâ€™t really make sense to me, but on a whole the original FMA was good. Iâ€™m still unsure on how I process the ending on the original series, I think I like it because it wasnâ€™t clichÃ© or safe. They kind of left it on a â€œwftâ€ sort of note and I respect that. Especially the movieâ€™s ending, Conqueror of Shamballa, which is supposed to be a conclusion to the original FMA series. 

Then I found out that â€œBrotherhoodâ€ wasnâ€™t a sequel, that it was in fact the true adaptation of the manga. So, I was like â€œOkay, Iâ€™ll give that a watch tooâ€ As I began to watch it, I wasnâ€™t that impressed, mostly because I felt like it was a cheap recreation of the original since the first 12-13 episodes are basically the same as the 04 series with minor changes. And I noticed that the Brotherhoodâ€™s animation was slightly more childlike, the characters chines were more circular instead of chiselled, and the show seemed to have more comedic segments than its predecessor. So, I was kind of scratching my head thinking â€œWhy do people say brotherhood is better?â€ But then I got around episode 15, and the story went in a totally different direction than the original. And from then on out I can safely say Brotherhood is a better show than the original. The characters are just far better intertwined and developed in Brotherhood. For example, in the original series Roy (Flame alchemist) is the killer of Winryâ€™s parents, and they never really resolve the issues, he admits to the murder, but she kind of just forgives him off screen and thatâ€™s it. In Brotherhood Scar is the murderer of Winryâ€™s parents, which makes a lot more sense because he was over in the war at the same time they were on opposing sides. And Scar and Winry get to have some screen time and get to a resolution about how she forgives him. And in the original 04 FMA Scar ends up dying for Lust, which comes out of nowhere and doesnâ€™t make any sense. Then he dies randomly after losing both arms. It just doesnâ€™t fit. Though I will admit the original series did a far better job on the whole Scar vs Kimblee fight, brotherhood fails in that area. I mean they build it up for them to fight, then some random ass Lion man kills Kimblee and thatâ€™s the end of his character basically, such a waste. And I didnâ€™t really like the ending of Brotherhood. Not only that Roy lost his vision and you never got to see him get it back, but also the way the relationships ended. I just sat through like 64 episodes I wanna see Ed kiss Winry for fucksake, show me some affection damn. Same thing goes for Roy & Hawkeye, you never see any real affection in this show. And the final episode, after all that trouble of getting Alâ€™s body back and shit, he just takes off by himself somewhere. Like â€œthanks for everything, now byeâ€ and the way Ed leaves Winry at the end, â€œI sort of love you, bye, cya in a couple months possibly yearsâ€ Thereâ€™s no way she isnâ€™t fucking the mailman when he gets back. it was just an unsatisfying ending.

In conclusion if you are struggling to decide which series to watch, FMA or FMAB, I would urge you to watch Brotherhood over the original. Thereâ€™s no real reason to watch the 04 version because itâ€™s just a random story separate from the true manga, but if you got the time why not watch both. 

Thank you, Fullmetal Alchemist & Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood.  It was an experience, until we meet again

Cya =)

Â @Fullmetal_Prodigy-03Â  Oh i'm not saying the original FMA series is bad, not a chance since it was one of my first late night animes as a kid i loved. I suggested brotherhood because of it being more faithful to the manga.

What is the problem with making a second season about Cyberpunk: Edgerunners? When Johnny Silverhand attacked Arasaka, it was also shown how he was shot by Adam Smesher, but the next shot showed him sitting alive as a hostage in the corporation. Moreover, Smesher himself told David that he would have made a good construct. David's death during the shooting was not well shown. As for Rebecca, the story took place in 2076, thanks to technology, it would have been possible to repair her and in the first episodes of the second season Arasaka could have held her hostage, threatening her with death if David (as a test subject) refused to work for the corporation and wanted to go against them. Lucy may have gone to the moon, but after a while (after the events in the game) she returned and heard that David was alive. After that, she gathered a team and organized an attack on Arasaka! This is my version of the continuation of the story, as I think it would be a great idea to make a season 2 based on the fact that Cyberpunk: Edgerunners successfully gained attention and increased sales for the game.

Having rewatched Edgerunners again (and having my heart broken again) what did it this time was obviously the final episode. But it was when Lucy told David how he was doing all this to satisfy his mom's dream or Maine's dream, but in reality, he said did all this for Lucy's dream. And she didn't know it. Meanwhile, Lucy was also protecting David in her own ways. And he didn't know it. All he knew was she was telling him to scaledown his cyberware (which was "one" way of protecting him"). So the tragedy of it all was miscommunication but also they didn't know just how much they loved each other.

Lain has very complecated plot imo. It could be seen as an allegory for a persons journey back from the material world to spirit. She starts as a normal girl but begins studying about computers and building advanced systems, realising that everyone is connected in this parallel world called wired. This could be the collective unconscious or "heaven". As time progresses lain become gradualy more detached from reality while delving deeper into this other world in a similar fashion that the enlightened person slowly withdrows from the material world of the flesh while omcreasing his presence in the spiritual realm. Mika on the other hand starts having all those messages from the wires about a prophesy but unlike Lain she eventually loses her mind and is rendered a mumbling mess. That could be symbolic of an awakening gone wrong, or a mental illness like psychosis. Then lain realizes her parents are not really her parents and that this world is not her true origin.          Eventually she comes in contact with a deceiving entity calling himself God ,which could be showing us the dangers of awakening, that wants her to kill herself trying to convince her that this body is trully useless and that she should allow for this world to become one with the wired.lain refuses acknowledging the importance of this material world and at that point this god entity becomes hostile. This might be symbolic of the darkness rushing to destroy an enlightened person before they break free from this illusive world. Lain wins though and eventually chooses to delete herself from existence and ascent to something higher. Thus why we see her at the end being everywhere at the same time. This is symbolic of the person who has fully awakened and is detached from this world and managed to find his true soul and essence. Some notes here are that her other self seen in some episodes that does bad things to her friends might be symbolic of her bad carnal flesh that she has to fight, or just another aspect of herself that she just became aware of.  Many theories can try to make sense of this anime and myself havent understood as much as i wanted to. I only saw it once though so maybe i jave missed some things. Still very interesting and confusing plot.

It really scared me when I first saw it at like age 13. I think Lain is a classic anime. But I always felt like the matrix totally stole ideas from Lain and for that I couldn't enjoy matrix..

This series is easy to misunderstand, and those that misunderstand tend to dislike, perhaps even hate it. They find this series boring to watch, perhaps even sleep-inducing. These people say that the concepts from the anime are tired and reused in the world of cyber-punk and that the series is poorly explained. I'm one of those people. Or at the very least, I find it boring and sleep-inducing.

This is awesome, but since I'm only on episode seven, I still have to say this... TOO MANY SPOILERS. MUST FINISH THIS ANIME NAO. Oh and btw, I love that movie. Thanks for including the soundtrack, it works with Lain well. :)

Funny because apparently Chiaki Konaka, who wrote the script, wrote for a short lived project of ABe's before Lain called Arisu in Cyberland. Which eventually was scrapped and just evolved into Lain, I think. I don't know man, I'm only on episode 7, maybe I should finish the series instead of trying to come up with all these newfangled theories. Though I think i can say you are quite accurate in your thoughts regarding it. :)

I'd rather say that Lain inspired both of them. The Coen brothers as well as others even stated (or rather implied) that the Matrix was inspired by both the GITS film and Lain. Donnie Darko didn't come until later. Perhaps it did inspire Donnie Darko, I could certainly see why because of that film being what it is. But no, you can't call Lain its love child because rather Lain gave birth to them. Though i haven't seen the whole series but I do have an inkling Lain is able to flipflop reality. :I
I guess you are not very familiar with Lain? :)

Based on their airing order, from the very beginning; Bakemonogatari.
After that, Nisemonogatari then Nekomonogatari: Black, then Monogatari Series Second Season, then Tsukimonogatari, then Owarimonogatari, oh yeah, watch Kizumonogatari trilogy if you curious at this point. Lastly, Zokuowarimonogatari. There is Koyomimonogatari but... You could ignored that.

First of all Monogatari and Tokyo Ghoul are nothing alike. Monogatari is a supernatural, mystery, comedy, psychological, romance anime while Tokyo Ghoul is a Action, Horror, Thriller anime.

Secondly Bakemonogatari anime was released in 2009 while the Tokyo Ghoul anime was released in 2014. So if anything Tokyo Ghoul took inspiration from Monogatari.

First of all Monogatari and Tokyo Ghoul are nothing alike. Monogatari is a supernatural, mystery, comedy, psychological, romance anime while Tokyo Ghoul is a Action, Horror, Thriller anime.

Secondly Bakemonogatari anime was released in 2009 while the Tokyo Ghoul anime was released in 2014. So if anything Tokyo Ghoul took inspiration from Monogatari.

Getting off the topic, I found out about this movie when the Scotiabank Theatre in my area was advertising it through a sign inside the lobby and (not knowing about LoveLive in the first place) I decided to go see it since it was only in theatres on a certain day at a certain time. I immediately started feeling uncomfortable when they were giving out â€œlimited editionâ€ posters to those of us going to see the movie and later that uncomfortable feeling was replaced with a cringey feeling that lasted for 2 hours straight. Aside from that, it was quite a decent experience and makes me laugh every time I think about it.

The movie still sucked though, I like it as an ironic experience but every time I try to take it seriously Iâ€™m either disappointed, bored, or both. The first season of this LoveLive was worse though, at least the characters in the movie felt developed enough to have a bit of an attachment to them (even though theyâ€™re still poorly written and generic for the most part).
